details.duration: 12 h periods until a cumulative dose of 630 kGy

challenge.description: Presence of Jahn-Teller distortion significantly affects the reversibility of lithium insertion/deinsertion processes and creates high cell polarization even at low cycling currents.
challenge.impact: Reduces the efficiency and stability of the material when used as a cathode in lithium-ion batteries.

solution.description: Defects were introduced via 60Co gamma irradiation to reduce the magnitude of Jahn-Teller distortion.
solution.methodology: Gamma irradiation was applied to induce structural and microstructural modifications, such as edge dislocations and ionic shifts.
solution.effectiveness: The solution reduced the Jahn-Teller distortion enthalpy by 24% in the first cycle and 28% in subsequent cycles, improving the material's performance.

evidence.data: DSC measurements showed reduced Jahn-Teller distortion enthalpy and improved cycling stability.

context.material_properties: Spinel structure with cubic symmetry; moderate stability and low theoretical energy density.
context.experimental_conditions: Gamma irradiation at doses of 100, 630, and 1000 kGy.
context.application_relevance: Improved cycling stability and reduced stress between particles enhance battery performance.

challenge.description: Small concentration of defects formed by gamma irradiation is difficult to detect in bulk samples using conventional XRD techniques.
challenge.impact: Limits the ability to characterize and understand the influence of defects on the material's properties.

solution.description: Advanced characterization techniques such as HRTEM and 7Li MAS NMR were employed to detect and analyze defects.
solution.methodology: High-resolution transmission electron microscopy and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy were used to study local structural changes and defect formation.
solution.effectiveness: Successfully identified edge dislocations, ionic shifts, and changes in atomic positions, providing insights into defect formation mechanisms.

evidence.data: HRTEM images showed edge dislocations and increased interlayer distances; 7Li MAS NMR spectra revealed changes in lithium ion distribution.

context.material_properties: Spinel structure with defects induced by gamma irradiation.
context.experimental_conditions: Characterization performed at room temperature using advanced microscopy and spectroscopy techniques.
context.application_relevance: Understanding defect formation is critical for optimizing material performance in batteries.

challenge.description: Nanometric samples exhibit different behavior compared to micrometric samples, with Jahn-Teller distortion absent in nanometric samples.
challenge.impact: Complicates the interpretation of results and the design of materials for specific applications.

solution.description: Investigated the influence of particle size and defect accumulation on Jahn-Teller distortion using DSC and XRD.
solution.methodology: Differential scanning calorimetry and X-ray diffraction were used to study the structural and thermal behavior of nanometric and micrometric samples.
solution.effectiveness: Revealed that smaller particle size prevents long-range cooperative Jahn-Teller effects, providing insights into material design.

evidence.data: DSC analysis showed no Jahn-Teller distortion in nanometric samples; XRD patterns indicated changes in lattice parameters with irradiation dose.

context.material_properties: Nanometric samples with smaller particle size and higher defect concentration.
context.experimental_conditions: Irradiation at doses of 100, 630, and 1000 kGy; testing performed at low temperatures.
context.application_relevance: Nanometric materials may offer improved stability and performance in battery applications.
